page.title: 02Place Names
page.content: Sutton Benger was already established in 1066 with "Sudtone" or "Sudtun" meaning south farmstead. Berenger was an under-tenant of Hullavington manor. The name is of Saxon origin and was pronounced "Burungurr", which was slurred in the broad Wessex manner to Benger. When a new housing estate was built in Sutton Benger in the 1970s the roads were named after well-known local figures, such as Lord Cowley, Farmer Lee, and Canon Westlake. Draycot Cerne was derived from "draeg- cot" which is old English for "cottages by a drag or combe", and from Henry de Cerne who was Lord of the Manor in 1228. Clanville in the north-west of the area was known as "Clane-fued" in 1256 - a typical mispronounciation of "Clean field".
